description: Barbados issued a warning against spreading false information on social media about the Government’s workplace policy in respect of Covid-19. Spreading false information about Government policies is prohibited under the Computer Misuse Act.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description: Barbados's Queen Elizabeth Hospital is restricting visiting hours. The new interim visiting hours across all general and surgical wards are 12:00 noon to 1:00 p.m. and 5:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. daily. Visits to the hospital’s Intensive Care Units – Medical Intensive Care Unit, Surgical Intensive Care Unit, Paediatric Intensive Care Unit, and Neonatal Intensive Care Unit – will be facilitated between 11:00 and 11:30 a.m.; 4:00 and 4:30 p.m.; and 5:30 and 6:00 p.m. Patients are only allowed 2 visitors at the time and visits cannot be longe than 2 hours. All visitors will be required to go through temperature tests at entrance.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Barbados enacts the Emergency Management (COVID-19) Curfew Directive, 2020. Under the Order, a curfew is in effect from Saturday, March 28, until Tuesday, April 14, while all businesses, except essential services and those identified, were ordered close as Government seeks to contain the spread of COVID-19. The curfew is between 8 pm and 6 am. Attorney General Dale Marshall announced that there will be a fine of $50,000, or one year in prison, or both, for anyone found guilty of breaking the curfew.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Barbados declares that it is currently in Stage 1 after the island recorded the first cases of COVID-19 on March 17th. Activation of National Emergency Operations Centre and Isolation Centre. Preparation of severe treatment facility and Paragon, St. Lucy District Hospital or Field Medical Hospital for screening, quarantine and isolation. Reconfiguring of polyclinics to facilitate local screening. Advice on limiting mass gathering to reduce risk for local spread. Suspension Of Visits & Closure Of Public Health Institutions.

description: 'Within 72 hours prior to departure for Barbados, all travellers from high risk countries are strongly encouraged to take a COVID-19 PCR test from an accredited laboratory (ISO, CAP, UKAS or equivalent). High risk countries are defined as those with more than 10,000 new cases in the prior seven days and community transmission. Travellers from low risk countries will have up to one week prior to departure for Barbados to take their tests. Low risk countries are defined as those with less than 100 new cases in the prior seven days and not in the Community Transmission Category.'
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Barbados authorities announced that new travel restrictions have been implemented as of Monday, August 3, amid the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. 
Travelers entering Barbados from high-risk countries are required to take a COVID-19 polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test and wait at the airport until the test results are received. Those who test negative are required to undergo a 14-day quarantine period. However, they will have the option to take a second test 5-7 days after the first and will be permitted to leave quarantine following a second negative test result.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Face masks are mandatory inside the airport at all times and a health screening questionnaire must be completed by all travelers at least 24 hours prior to arrival.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
The Government of Barbados has implemented a travel ‘Bubble’ for specific countries with a low incidence of COVID-19, effective August 5, 2020. They are St. Vincent, St. Lucia, Dominica, St. Kitts and Nevis and Grenada.
Under these new travel protocols, persons travelling within the ‘Bubble’ who have not travelled to or transited through any high, medium or low-risk country within 21 days prior to travel to Barbados, will not be required to take a COVID-19 PCR test prior to or on arrival and do not require monitoring during their stay.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: With effect from September 19th,  it is mandatory for all persons travelling to Barbados from High, and Medium risk countries  to take a COVID-19 PCR test from an accredited or certified facility/laboratory within 72 hours prior to arrival, in order to enter the country. Persons travelling from Low-Risk countries are strongly advised to take, and will be allowed to present results of tests taken up to 5 days prior to arrival, in order to expedite processing through the airport. Relevant accrediting bodies and standards include: ISO:15189, CAP, UKAS or the equivalent.

description:
"50 Countries Now In COVID-19 High Risk Category. the new countries which have moved into high risk are Antigua and Barbuda, Cayman Islands, Cuba, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Ghana, Greece, Iceland, Japan, Martinique, Norway, Sri Lanka and the United Arab Emirates. 
Five countries are now deemed medium risk for entry.  These are Australia, Bermuda, New Zealand, St. Lucia and St. Vincent and the Grenadines.
It is mandatory that all persons travelling to Barbados from high and medium risk countries have a negative COVID-19 PCR test done at an accredited or certified facility within three days prior to arrival.
Persons arriving from Canada, however, are allowed to be tested on arrival in Barbados, if they are unable to receive their test results in time for departure from their country."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In accordance with the country's Health Services Act Cap 44, all food delivery workers are required to pass health report at the beginning of the shift. Temperature test upon entering the workplace. They are also required to follow social distance in case if they need to communicate with other employees, they must be provided medical masks and discard the disposal ones after 4 hours of wear/or wash reusable ones after each shift. They need wash their hands after each food delivery, sanitize all surfaces and all utensils must be sealed.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Barbados: The Environmental Health Department, in the Ministry of Health and Wellness, has developed a framework geared towards ensuring the safe management of food service establishments during the COVID-19 crisis. This is designed to work in conjunction with the domestic health regulations,Health Services Act Cap 44, and the purpose is to increase the safety in the light of COVID-19 crisis. Under this new framework, all food service establishments are required to clean and sanitize their premises before and after work hours and food service workers are required to wear masks and sanitize after each food delivery.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Barbados recommends contractors to consider staggered work hours for their employees in accordance with the COVID-19 Framework for the Recommencement of the Construction Industry. Workers should go home right after the work to avoid crowing in public transport and observe social distancing while using toilets. Contractors should sanitize surfaces and provide their employees with separate towels, closed bins and a separate water.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: As a part of Phase 3 (May 18-31) of re-opening the country, new protocol for hairdressing salons is established in The Health Services Act CAP.44 (Hairdressers) Regulations 1970 and further enhanced in the light of COVID-19 crisis. New protocol has provisions on: face shields on service providers and customers, cleaning & sanitizing work stations and restrooms, making appointments with clients, social distancing in salons, as well as more detailed instructions on cleaning/discarding shampoo and pedicure bowls after each client.

description:
Senior Medical officer of Health Dr Leslie Rollock announced that asymptomatic arrivals, considered at low risk, will continue to be self-quarantined at home for 14 days, while anyone arriving with symptoms will be sent directly to the Isolation Unit at Enmore. 
The temporary quarantine centre set up to receive persons arriving in Barbados from China and other regions impacted by the COVID-19 is ready to be deployed, and can be operational at a moment’s notice. The centre would receive anyone, who, on arrival at the ports of entry, was screened and determined to have been at high risk of exposure, even though they are asymptomatic.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
With immediate effect, all arriving passengers who have been in Iran, or Lombardy, Emilia-Romagna or Veneto in Italy in the previous 14 days will be required to report to Port Health at the points of entry. 
These passengers will be interviewed by port health officers and sent to mandatory quarantine. The type of quarantine is determined by the level of risk of exposure. Low-risk individuals, he explained, are sent to home quarantine while moderate to high-risk individuals are sent to mandatory quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Barbados Ministry of Tourism’s updated travel protocols came into effect on August 3rd. These protocols state that “persons from High-Risk countries with a valid negative COVID-19 PCR test result will be quarantined at a designated holding hotel or approved villa at their own expense, or free of charge at a government facility, and will be monitored daily for the onset of symptoms. These persons will be quarantined for a period of 14 days with an option to take a second COVID-19 PCR test between 5-7 days after the last test accepted by the Ministry of Health and Wellness. Persons will typically be released once the test result is negative.” “High-Risk: Includes USA, Brazil, India, Mexico, Argentina, Peru, Colombia, South Africa, Indonesia, Philippines and Russia.”
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
People arriving in Barbados with a negative COVID-19 PRC test from countries categorised as high risk are required to quarantine at a government facility free of charge, or at a designated hotel or approved villa at their own expense.
A villa for the purpose of quarantine is defined in the updated travel protocols, which came into effect today, Friday, September 4, as a self-contained accommodation unit, which shares no common areas with other properties such as gyms, laundry rooms or swimming pools.

description:
It is mandatory for all persons arriving in Barbados from countries categorised as high risk to go into quarantine for a period of four to five days from the receipt of their first valid negative COVID-19 PCR test. At the end of the period, they are retested and if they continue to be negative for the virus are discharged from quarantine.
Persons in breach in any of the above stipulations will, on summary conviction, be subject to a fine of BDS $50,000, imprisonment for one year, or both.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: Flight attendants and pilots flying into Barbados' Grantley Adams International Airport are being subjected to strict COVID-19 protocols for their safety and that of passengers. Crew, who are in Barbados for 48 hours or less, are not required to take a PCR test, but have to go immediately into quarantine
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
It is mandatory that all persons travelling to Barbados from high and medium risk countries have a negative COVID-19 PCR test done at an accredited or certified facility within three days prior to arrival. 

Persons arriving from Canada, however, are allowed to be tested on arrival in Barbados, if they are unable to receive their test results in time for departure from their country. 

All high risk passengers are required to quarantine at a designated hotel or approved villa at their own expense or free of charge at a government facility, up to the time of a second test, which will be four to five days after the first test. 

At the end of the period, if they test negative, they are discharged from quarantine, but will continue to be monitored for seven days from the time of arrival. 
Passengers from medium risk countries are monitored for seven days after arrival and must also undergo a second test within four to five days. 
Persons from low risk countries are strongly advised to have a negative test taken within five days of arrival, and those who arrive without it will be tested on arrival. As of November 3, 50 countries are included in the "High Risk" category
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Countries classified as low, medium or high risk.
Passengers from high risk and medium risk countries required to show negative results from a COVID-19 PCR test completed within 3 days of arrival.
Those considered to be from high risk countries required to quarantine for 4 or 5 days until they take a second PCR test (will no longer be required to quarantine if test is negative but will be monitored for an additional 7 days). 
Those from medium risk countries will not be required to quarantine but will be monitored for 4/5 days until they take a second test (will be released if test is negative but will be monitored for an additional 7 days).
Those from low risk countries tested on arrival.

description:
Persons from High-Risk countries with a valid negative COVID-19 PCR test result will be quarantined at a designated holding hotel or approved villa at their own expense, and will be monitored daily for the onset of symptoms.
Beginning January 6, all persons in quarantine will be required to wear an electronic tracking bracelet. Tampering with the electronic monitoring bracelet will send an alarm to Barbados authorities.

description:
All arrivals are required to take a rapid antigen test on arrival.
Travelers who test negative are required to complete a mandatory quarantine period at a government-approved quarantine location before another PCR test is administered on the traveler's fifth day in-country.

description:
ALL travellers into Barbados, inclusive of those deemed fully vaccinated, are asked to review, and indicate their acceptance of the following:
ALL travellers must travel with a valid negative Standard COVID-19 PCR test result.
Fully vaccinated travelers will take a 2nd test on arrival and will quarantine until they get the result (total 1-2 days). 
Unvaccinated travelers will take a 2nd test 5 days after arrival and will quarantine until they get the result (total 7-8 days).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Barbados's Minister of  Small Business, Entrepreneurship and Commerce, Dwight Sutherland, announced that businesses which should not be operating during this time under the COVID-19 restrictions may face disciplinary action for failing to adhere. He mentioned that Attorney General will "enforce" the closure of businesses through the Emergency Management Act legislation.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Barbados National Standards Institution (BNSI) is implementing a "Safe Business Certification Mark" to make sure that the workplaces, the small businesses, put the necessary health and  safety regulations in place that  persons can feel comfortable with returning  to work. Micro, Small and Medium business will be receive "Occupational Health and Safety" certification by the Ministry of Commerce. This new standard was aligned with the ISO 45001 Occupational Health and Safety Standard, which is the World Standard for Occupational Health and Safety.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required,Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Barbados is limiting public access to the Community Legal Services Commission suite of offices at the Supreme Court Complex. Members of the public who wish to inquire about, or apply for legal aid services, are asked to first make initial contact with the department by calling 535-9900. A decision will then be made as to whether the caller should attend at the office in person, or be interviewed via telephone.

description: The Barbados Postal Service has advised that the Post Office will not be accepting mail for international destinations, as this service will be temporarily suspended as of March 23. Incoming international mail will still be processed. Local mail services will continue to operate.

description: The Royal Barbados Police Force (RBPF) is closing police station tours for groups and schools as of March 17, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Barbados introduces new shopping schedules during the country's 24-hr curfew. Persons whose surnames begin with A and B, are to shop on Mondays between 8-11 AM and Fridays between 1-4 PM. Their Banking day is Monday between 9AM and 1PM. Persons whose surnames begin with C, D, E & F - shopping on Wed between 8-11 AM and Sat 1-4 PM. Banking day for them is Wednesday between 9AM - 1PM. Persons whose surnames begin with G, H, I, J & K - shopping on Thursday between 8-11AM and Monday 1-4PM. Banking day for them is Thursday between 9AM - 1PM. Persons whose surnames begin with L, M, N, O, P, Q, R - shop on Friday 8-11AM and on Tuesday 1-4PM. Banking day for them is Friday from 9AM to 1PM. Persons with surnames from S-Z: shop on Saturday 8-11 AM and Wednesday 1-4PM; while banking day for them is Wednesday 9AM til 1PM. Senior citizens shop on Tuesdays and Sundays from 8 - 11AM and their banking day is Tuesday between 9AM and 1PM. Essential/healthcare workers to shop on Thursday 1-4PM and Sundays 11AM - 2PM and use banks on Thursday 1-4PM. All persons must carry their IDs at all times because they will have to show it before entering the premises. People are also advised to wear masks and carry umbrellas/water in case of long lines.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Effective Wednesday, July 1, there will be no curfews in Barbados.
Prime Minister Mia Amor Mottley made this announcement today in her address to the nation.
She also revealed that the physical distancing protocol would now be one metre, “that is just about three feet or in other words, outside of the stretch of your arms and hands”, Prime Minister Mottley stated.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
